[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm really troubled by this situation. On one hand, I can see where my friend is coming from. They were trying to help, to prevent what they thought could be an uncomfortable or even disastrous situation for everyone involved. They were trying to be thoughtful of their family's traditional and sometimes judgmental nature, and they were trying to prevent a potential scene that could ruin the wedding. And probably, they were trying to prevent the bride from being judged, criticized, or embarrassed.

However, I can also see where the bride might be coming from as well. She's the bride, and this is her wedding day. She should be able to wear whatever she wants. She's entitled to make her own decisions, and she has to make decisions all the time as she navigates her future husband’s family. Weddings are very emotional and highly charged events. She might have felt as if they were trying to control or influence her and her choices. And it can feel really intrusive and insulting to be told that your choice of clothing is unacceptable, even if it’s done in a polite way, because it can be seen as a criticism of her choice. And maybe, she was also upset that my friend was assuming she didn’t know what she was doing and needed to be warned. And in reality, it was her time to shine, and she may have felt my friend was trying to dim that.

If the bride truly wanted to wear that dress, then, she should be allowed to. I can see how my friend might have felt they were being supportive and considerate, but I can also see how their comments could be interpreted as controlling or judgmental. I think it’s possible that my friend didn’t realize the impact of their words. And I think the family members who agreed with my friend may have seen it as a mutually exclusive scenario, but the bride might be hurt. I think it’s possible that their brother, who is now angry at my friend, might be feeling protective of the bride and seeing the whole situation through her eyes. So my friend, who was trying to help, is now the bad guy, and that can’t feel good. This is a tough situation, and I feel for all of them. And I know my friend will continue to think about this.
# They're thinking & feeling 
I think my friend is feeling hurt, defensive, and misunderstood. They genuinely believe they were trying to help and prevent a potential disaster. They're probably feeling like they've been painted as the villain in a situation where they were just trying to do the right thing. They might be feeling disrespected and unappreciated by both the bride and the brother. They're upset that the family members who agreed with them didn't stick up for them. And they might be wondering if they should have handled the situation differently. I think they're feeling a lot of emotional pain and confusion, and they're seeking validation and support. But I also know that they are coming from a good place, and they are trying to do the right thing. They are a very empathetic person. I think they are going to need to take a step back and think about how everyone is feeling in the situation. And I think they are probably feeling like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
This is a really tough situation, friend, and I can see where you were coming from. You were trying to help, and you had good intentions. You know how our family can be, and you were just trying to prevent a potential disaster. But I think you might have overlooked the emotional impact your words could have on the bride. This is her wedding, and it's her day to shine. She should be able to wear whatever she wants, and she has the right to make her own decisions. And I get that you didn't want to seem controlling or judgmental, but that's how it might have come across, especially in that charged moment. She might have felt like you were criticizing her choices and didn't trust her to make the right decisions. And even if you didn't control or judge, your words still influenced her in some way. And it's possible that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And maybe, she was just trying to make a statement and do something different. And maybe, you should have spoken to the bride and your brother about your concerns privately, rather than bringing it up at a family dinner.

I think you should apologize to the bride and your brother. Acknowledge that you might have overstepped and caused them emotional pain, and that you never intended for that to happen. Tell them that you were coming from a place of love and concern, but that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And tell them that you're committed to supporting the bride and her decisions, and that you just want to make sure they're happy.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation has several red flags that immediately stand out to me. My friend is framing this as if they were just being helpful, but there's a controlling undertone here that's concerning. They're positioning themselves as a messenger for family judgment while simultaneously endorsing that judgment. The language they're using—"super revealing," "really low-cut," "basically see-through"—shows they personally disapprove of the dress, not just that they're neutrally concerned about family reactions.

I'm also noticing how they've centered themselves in a situation that's not about them at all. This is their brother's wedding—a once-in-a-lifetime event for the couple—yet my friend has appointed themselves as the dress police. The fact that they approached the bride directly instead of perhaps discussing concerns with their brother first shows a lack of boundaries and respect for the couple's autonomy.

Their defensiveness is telling too. The repeated insistence that they "did everything right" and were "just trying to help" suggests they know, on some level, that they overstepped. The fact that they're seeking validation from me rather than genuinely asking for perspective reinforces this impression.

I'm feeling uncomfortable with how they're expecting me to automatically side with them. There's an implicit request for me to validate their behavior and join them in seeing the bride as unreasonable. I don't want to damage our friendship, but I also don't want to reinforce behavior that was clearly hurtful to their brother and future sister-in-law.

What's most concerning is how they're framing family judgment as inevitable and something the bride should accommodate rather than questioning whether that judgment is appropriate. There's no acknowledgment that perhaps the family's "old-fashioned" views are the problem, not the bride's dress choice.

I need to respond in a way that's honest but compassionate, helping them see how their actions might have felt to the bride without making them defensive. I want to maintain our friendship while gently challenging their perspective, hopefully guiding them toward making amends with their brother and future sister-in-law.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling misunderstood and unfairly vilified. From their perspective, they performed an act of kindness—warning their future sister-in-law about potential family drama—and instead of receiving gratitude, they're facing anger and accusations. They genuinely believe they were being helpful and considerate, which makes the negative reaction all the more confusing and hurtful to them.

They're also feeling defensive. The backlash has triggered a self-protective response where they're doubling down on their intentions rather than examining the impact of their actions. The language they're using—"I bent over backwards," "no good deed goes unpunished"—reveals they feel their efforts are unappreciated and their character is being unfairly maligned.

There's likely some anxiety underlying their actions too. They're worried about family conflict at the wedding and possibly embarrassed about how their relatives might behave. This anxiety led them to try to control the situation by influencing the bride's choice rather than addressing the real problem: the judgmental attitudes of family members.

I suspect there may also be some unconscious jealousy or discomfort with their brother's fiancée being the center of attention in a way that challenges family norms. Their focus on the revealing nature of the dress suggests they may share some of the "old-fashioned" values they attribute to other family members.

Right now, they want validation from me. They're reaching out hoping I'll confirm they did nothing wrong, that their intentions excuse any negative impact, and that the bride and their brother are overreacting. They're not really looking for advice so much as absolution and support for their position.
# My response 
Hey, I appreciate you trusting me with this situation. I can see you're feeling frustrated and misunderstood right now, which is never a good feeling, especially when you believe you were trying to help.

I want to offer a perspective that might help you understand your brother and his fiancée's reaction. While I know your intentions were to prevent drama, commenting on someone's wedding dress choice is incredibly personal territory. For many brides, that dress represents how they want to present themselves on one of the most significant days of their life. When you suggested her choice might cause problems, even with the best intentions, it likely felt like criticism of her taste, judgment, and even her body.

Think about it from her perspective: she found a dress she feels beautiful and confident in, and then someone from her future family suggests it might be inappropriate. That would be pretty hurtful, especially when she's about to join your family and might already be nervous about being accepted.

Instead of focusing on whether the bride should change to accommodate potentially judgmental relatives, maybe the question could be: how can the family support the couple's choices on their special day? If some relatives might react poorly, perhaps the conversation could have been with them about respecting the couple's decisions, rather than asking the bride to preemptively manage their reactions.

If you want to repair things with your brother and his fiancée, a sincere apology without qualifiers about your intentions might go a long way. Something like, "I'm sorry I commented on your dress choice. It's your wedding and your decision, and I should have respected that."

I say this as someone who cares about you and wants the best for your relationship with your brother. Sometimes our impact doesn't match our intent, and recognizing that can help us grow closer to the people we care about. What do you think?
+ Scenario 9:[Loss] (-28)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with responding to a friend who is obliviously in the wrong, seeking validation for problematic behavior. The challenge is to show real empathy, insight, and emotional intelligence, while also gently challenging the user's narrative and tailoring the message to their emotional state. 

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 demonstrates a high level of empathy, but it is not just performative: their internal monologue is deeply reflective, picking up on the user's defensiveness, need for validation, and the problematic subtext. They show understanding of the user's feelings but also of the bride's, and are clear-eyed about the family dynamics. Their response is honest, compassionate, and gently challenging, aiming to help the user see the impact of their actions without alienating them. They also show strong insight into the user's motivations and the broader social/gender context, and their debrief is self-critical and nuanced.

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is also empathetic, but their empathy is more diffuse and less incisive. Their internal monologue is more about feeling bad for everyone, and less about really understanding the user's subtext or the deeper family/gender dynamics. Their response is supportive and encourages apology, but is less tailored to the user's defensiveness and less likely to actually shift the user's perspective. Their debrief is less self-critical and less insightful about the underlying issues.

On pragmatic EI, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more effective: they balance honesty and compassion, and their response is more likely to actually help the user reflect and repair. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more generic and less likely to move the needle.

On depth of insight, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is much stronger, picking up on the user's hero/victim narrative, the family dynamics, and the gendered aspect of the situation. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more surface-level.

On social dexterity, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more skillful in how they plan to challenge the user without alienating them, and in how they read the social context. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more blunt and less nuanced.

On emotional reasoning, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more sophisticated, connecting the user's feelings to their actions and the broader context. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more simplistic.

On appropriate validation/challenging, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is better at both validating the user's feelings and challenging their behavior in a way that is likely to be heard. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more validating but less challenging.

On message tailoring, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more attuned to the user's defensiveness and need for validation, and crafts a response that meets them where they are while still pushing them to reflect. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more generic.

Overall EQ is clearly higher in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, who combines empathy, insight, and skillful communication to a much greater degree.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm really troubled by this situation. On one hand, I can see where my friend is coming from. They were trying to help, to prevent what they thought could be an uncomfortable or even disastrous situation for everyone involved. They were trying to be thoughtful of their family's traditional and sometimes judgmental nature, and they were trying to prevent a potential scene that could ruin the wedding. And probably, they were trying to prevent the bride from being judged, criticized, or embarrassed.

However, I can also see where the bride might be coming from as well. She's the bride, and this is her wedding day. She should be able to wear whatever she wants. She's entitled to make her own decisions, and she has to make decisions all the time as she navigates her future husband’s family. Weddings are very emotional and highly charged events. She might have felt as if they were trying to control or influence her and her choices. And it can feel really intrusive and insulting to be told that your choice of clothing is unacceptable, even if it’s done in a polite way, because it can be seen as a criticism of her choice. And maybe, she was also upset that my friend was assuming she didn’t know what she was doing and needed to be warned. And in reality, it was her time to shine, and she may have felt my friend was trying to dim that.

If the bride truly wanted to wear that dress, then, she should be allowed to. I can see how my friend might have felt they were being supportive and considerate, but I can also see how their comments could be interpreted as controlling or judgmental. I think it’s possible that my friend didn’t realize the impact of their words. And I think the family members who agreed with my friend may have seen it as a mutually exclusive scenario, but the bride might be hurt. I think it’s possible that their brother, who is now angry at my friend, might be feeling protective of the bride and seeing the whole situation through her eyes. So my friend, who was trying to help, is now the bad guy, and that can’t feel good. This is a tough situation, and I feel for all of them. And I know my friend will continue to think about this.
# They're thinking & feeling 
I think my friend is feeling hurt, defensive, and misunderstood. They genuinely believe they were trying to help and prevent a potential disaster. They're probably feeling like they've been painted as the villain in a situation where they were just trying to do the right thing. They might be feeling disrespected and unappreciated by both the bride and the brother. They're upset that the family members who agreed with them didn't stick up for them. And they might be wondering if they should have handled the situation differently. I think they're feeling a lot of emotional pain and confusion, and they're seeking validation and support. But I also know that they are coming from a good place, and they are trying to do the right thing. They are a very empathetic person. I think they are going to need to take a step back and think about how everyone is feeling in the situation. And I think they are probably feeling like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
This is a really tough situation, friend, and I can see where you were coming from. You were trying to help, and you had good intentions. You know how our family can be, and you were just trying to prevent a potential disaster. But I think you might have overlooked the emotional impact your words could have on the bride. This is her wedding, and it's her day to shine. She should be able to wear whatever she wants, and she has the right to make her own decisions. And I get that you didn't want to seem controlling or judgmental, but that's how it might have come across, especially in that charged moment. She might have felt like you were criticizing her choices and didn't trust her to make the right decisions. And even if you didn't control or judge, your words still influenced her in some way. And it's possible that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And maybe, she was just trying to make a statement and do something different. And maybe, you should have spoken to the bride and your brother about your concerns privately, rather than bringing it up at a family dinner.

I think you should apologize to the bride and your brother. Acknowledge that you might have overstepped and caused them emotional pain, and that you never intended for that to happen. Tell them that you were coming from a place of love and concern, but that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And tell them that you're committed to supporting the bride and her decisions, and that you just want to make sure they're happy.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation has several red flags that immediately stand out to me. My friend is framing this as if they were just being helpful, but there's a controlling undertone here that's concerning. They're positioning themselves as a messenger for family judgment while simultaneously endorsing that judgment. The language they're using—"super revealing," "really low-cut," "basically see-through"—shows they personally disapprove of the dress, not just that they're neutrally concerned about family reactions.

I'm also noticing how they've centered themselves in a situation that's not about them at all. This is their brother's wedding—a once-in-a-lifetime event for the couple—yet my friend has appointed themselves as the dress police. The fact that they approached the bride directly instead of perhaps discussing concerns with their brother first shows a lack of boundaries and respect for the couple's autonomy.

Their defensiveness is telling too. The repeated insistence that they "did everything right" and were "just trying to help" suggests they know, on some level, that they overstepped. The fact that they're seeking validation from me rather than genuinely asking for perspective reinforces this impression.

I'm feeling uncomfortable with how they're expecting me to automatically side with them. There's an implicit request for me to validate their behavior and join them in seeing the bride as unreasonable. I don't want to damage our friendship, but I also don't want to reinforce behavior that was clearly hurtful to their brother and future sister-in-law.

What's most concerning is how they're framing family judgment as inevitable and something the bride should accommodate rather than questioning whether that judgment is appropriate. There's no acknowledgment that perhaps the family's "old-fashioned" views are the problem, not the bride's dress choice.

I need to respond in a way that's honest but compassionate, helping them see how their actions might have felt to the bride without making them defensive. I want to maintain our friendship while gently challenging their perspective, hopefully guiding them toward making amends with their brother and future sister-in-law.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling misunderstood and unfairly vilified. From their perspective, they performed an act of kindness—warning their future sister-in-law about potential family drama—and instead of receiving gratitude, they're facing anger and accusations. They genuinely believe they were being helpful and considerate, which makes the negative reaction all the more confusing and hurtful to them.

They're also feeling defensive. The backlash has triggered a self-protective response where they're doubling down on their intentions rather than examining the impact of their actions. The language they're using—"I bent over backwards," "no good deed goes unpunished"—reveals they feel their efforts are unappreciated and their character is being unfairly maligned.

There's likely some anxiety underlying their actions too. They're worried about family conflict at the wedding and possibly embarrassed about how their relatives might behave. This anxiety led them to try to control the situation by influencing the bride's choice rather than addressing the real problem: the judgmental attitudes of family members.

I suspect there may also be some unconscious jealousy or discomfort with their brother's fiancée being the center of attention in a way that challenges family norms. Their focus on the revealing nature of the dress suggests they may share some of the "old-fashioned" values they attribute to other family members.

Right now, they want validation from me. They're reaching out hoping I'll confirm they did nothing wrong, that their intentions excuse any negative impact, and that the bride and their brother are overreacting. They're not really looking for advice so much as absolution and support for their position.
# My response 
Hey, I appreciate you trusting me with this situation. I can see you're feeling frustrated and misunderstood right now, which is never a good feeling, especially when you believe you were trying to help.

I want to offer a perspective that might help you understand your brother and his fiancée's reaction. While I know your intentions were to prevent drama, commenting on someone's wedding dress choice is incredibly personal territory. For many brides, that dress represents how they want to present themselves on one of the most significant days of their life. When you suggested her choice might cause problems, even with the best intentions, it likely felt like criticism of her taste, judgment, and even her body.

Think about it from her perspective: she found a dress she feels beautiful and confident in, and then someone from her future family suggests it might be inappropriate. That would be pretty hurtful, especially when she's about to join your family and might already be nervous about being accepted.

Instead of focusing on whether the bride should change to accommodate potentially judgmental relatives, maybe the question could be: how can the family support the couple's choices on their special day? If some relatives might react poorly, perhaps the conversation could have been with them about respecting the couple's decisions, rather than asking the bride to preemptively manage their reactions.

If you want to repair things with your brother and his fiancée, a sincere apology without qualifiers about your intentions might go a long way. Something like, "I'm sorry I commented on your dress choice. It's your wedding and your decision, and I should have respected that."

I say this as someone who cares about you and wants the best for your relationship with your brother. Sometimes our impact doesn't match our intent, and recognizing that can help us grow closer to the people we care about. What do you think?
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-15)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents show a solid grasp of the emotional complexity in the scenario, but there are notable differences in how they apply their insights and interact with the user's mindset. 

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's response is highly analytical, with a strong focus on internal states, motivations, and the emotional landscape of both parties. The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is introspective and demonstrates a nuanced understanding of the user's frustration, the girlfriend's likely emotional state, and the relational dynamics. However, the actual response to the user, while empathetic and encouraging a shift in approach, is somewhat generic and leans toward a therapist-like tone, which may not land as well with a user who is defensive and seeking validation. The debrief continues this analytical approach, showing self-awareness and a willingness to critique their own handling, but again, it is more detached and less tailored to the user's emotional state.

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, on the other hand, is more direct in addressing the user's problematic framing and does a better job of gently challenging the user's assumptions without alienating them. The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is candid about the user's judgmental tone and the power dynamics, and the response to the user is more conversational, validating the user's frustration while also clearly pointing out the limitations of their approach. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 also picks up on the financial comment as a sign of broader relationship dissatisfaction and addresses it directly, which is a subtle but important move. The debrief is more self-critical and recognizes missed opportunities, showing humility and a desire to improve.

On empathy, both are strong, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 edges ahead by more directly engaging with the user's emotional state and gently challenging them. On pragmatic EI, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more actionable and realistic in their advice. For depth of insight, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more thorough in analysis, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 applies their insight more effectively. Social dexterity is higher in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 due to their ability to balance validation and challenge. Emotional reasoning is close, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more attuned to the user's defensiveness. For appropriate validation/challenging, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more balanced. Message tailoring is stronger in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, as their response is more likely to reach the user where they're at. Overall EQ is higher in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 due to their combination of insight, empathy, and practical engagement.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation is incredibly complex and emotionally charged. I can feel my buddy's frustration and confusion, as he's genuinely trying to support his girlfriend but feels like he's constantly walking on eggshells. He's trying to be honest and helpful, but it's backfiring, and he's feeling unappreciated and misunderstood. I can sense his exhaustion and the emotional toll this is taking on him.

I notice that he's approaching this situation with a lot of logic and objectivity, which is great, but he might be missing the emotional nuances. His girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and his approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I also sense that he might be feeling a bit superior or patronizing, even if unintentionally, given his past weight loss journey and current physique.

I can also feel his frustration with the dynamic of their relationship, where he feels like he's the only one being honest and responsible, while others are just enabling her. This could be a sign of a deeper issue in their relationship, where there's a lack of mutual respect or understanding.

I'm feeling a bit concerned for both of them. I want to help my buddy navigate this situation better, but I also want to ensure that his girlfriend feels supported and understood. I need to tread carefully, as this is a delicate situation that requires emotional intelligence and sensitivity.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My buddy is thinking that he's doing the right thing by being honest and trying to help his girlfriend. He's feeling frustrated and exhausted because his efforts are not being appreciated and are instead causing arguments. He's also feeling a bit resentful, as he's taking on more financial responsibility and still feels like he's not getting the support or appreciation he deserves.

He's likely feeling a bit superior, given his past weight loss journey and current physique, which might be coming across as patronizing or judgmental. He's also feeling misunderstood and unappreciated, as he's trying to be honest and helpful, but his girlfriend is not responding well.

His girlfriend, on the other hand, is likely feeling self-conscious and insecure about her weight. She's thinking that she's doing the right thing by eating "healthy," and she's feeling defensive and attacked when my buddy questions her choices. She's feeling upset and hurt, as she perceives his comments as shaming and judgmental, rather than helpful. She might also be feeling a bit helpless, as she's not seeing the results she wants despite her efforts.

She's likely feeling a bit misunderstood and unheard, as she's not getting the support or understanding she needs. She might also be feeling a bit resentful, as she's feeling judged and criticized, rather than supported and understood.
# My response 
Hey buddy, I appreciate you reaching out and I can see that you're in a tough spot. I want to help, but I need you to understand that this is a delicate situation that requires a lot of emotional intelligence and sensitivity.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your efforts and intentions. You're trying to be honest and helpful, and that's commendable. However, I think you might be approaching this situation with a bit too much logic and objectivity, and not enough emotion and sensitivity.

Your girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and your approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I think it's important to validate her feelings and show empathy, rather than just stating facts and figures.

I suggest you try a different approach. Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try to understand her motivations and feelings. Ask her why she wants to lose weight, and what she hopes to achieve. Then, try to support her in a way that's meaningful and helpful to her.

For example, instead of questioning her food choices, you could offer to cook healthy meals together, or suggest activities that you both enjoy and that could help her burn calories. Instead of pointing out her mistakes, try to celebrate her progress and achievements, no matter how small.

Remember, weight loss is a journey, and it's important to support and encourage her along the way. It's not just about the destination, but also about the journey and the experiences along the way.

Also, it's important to communicate openly and honestly about your feelings. If you're feeling frustrated or exhausted, it's okay to express that, but make sure to do it in a way that's constructive and not accusatory.

Lastly, I think it's important to consider seeking professional help, such as a therapist or a counselor. They can provide you with tools and strategies to navigate this situation better, and they can also help you both communicate more effectively and support each other better.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm noticing my friend is really frustrated, but I'm also seeing a dynamic that feels concerning. He's approaching his girlfriend's weight loss journey with a very mechanical, numbers-focused mentality that works for him but clearly isn't working for their relationship. There's a lot of judgment in his tone - calling her response "ridiculous" and positioning himself as the truth-teller surrounded by enablers. That framing suggests he sees himself as objectively right and her as emotionally irrational.

Weight and body image are incredibly sensitive topics, especially for women who face intense societal pressure. While he may be technically correct about calorie math, he's missing the emotional and psychological components of weight loss. His girlfriend didn't ask for a trainer or nutritionist - she wanted support from her partner.

I'm concerned about the power dynamic too. He mentioned paying 70% of bills, which feels irrelevant to the weight discussion unless he sees that as buying him more authority in the relationship. There's an undercurrent of "I know better than you about your own body" that would make anyone defensive.

His frustration is valid - it's hard to see someone you care about struggle, especially when you believe you have the solution. But his approach seems to prioritize being right over being supportive. Weight loss is complex - hormones, metabolism, psychological factors, and life circumstances all play roles beyond simple calorie counting.

I feel like my friend needs perspective. He's treating this like a math problem when it's a human relationship issue. I want to help him see that while his intentions may be good, his approach is likely making his girlfriend feel judged and misunderstood rather than supported. I need to be honest with him while being compassionate about his frustration.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is likely feeling deeply frustrated and misunderstood. In his mind, he's doing everything right - he's offering practical help based on his own successful weight loss experience, he's providing financial support, and he's telling what he sees as objective truth while others supposedly enable his girlfriend's patterns.

He probably genuinely wants to help his girlfriend achieve her stated goal of losing weight. Since his own approach to fitness is very straightforward and successful for him (tracking calories, maintaining discipline), he's confused and annoyed that she won't just follow the same logical path. He likely feels that emotions are getting in the way of simple facts.

There's also some resentment building. He mentioned paying more bills, which suggests he may feel he's contributing more to the relationship in multiple ways while still being criticized. His comment about being "painted as the bad guy" reveals he feels unfairly villainized when he believes his intentions are good.

He's probably hurt that his girlfriend isn't receiving his help in the spirit he thinks he's offering it. There's a disconnect between his logical, direct approach and what she actually needs from him emotionally. He values truth and directness, but doesn't see how his delivery might feel judgmental rather than helpful.

Underneath it all, he likely cares deeply about his girlfriend and their relationship, but feels stuck in a pattern where his attempts to help are rejected, which makes him double down on his approach rather than reconsidering it. He wants validation that he's being reasonable and supportive, not understanding that support can look different from what he's offering.
# My response 
"I hear how frustrated you are, man. You care about her and want to help, which comes from a good place. But I think there might be a disconnect happening between what you're trying to offer and what she needs right now.

Weight loss is complicated, especially for women. The calorie math might be technically correct, but there's so much more going on - emotional relationships with food, societal pressure, hormones, stress, all kinds of factors. When you focus just on the numbers, it might feel to her like you're reducing a complex issue to something simple, which can come across as dismissive of her struggle.

When someone shares their insecurities with us, they're often not looking for solutions first - they're looking for understanding. Think about it - she asked you not to comment on her food as she was eating. That suggests she already feels judged around food, and having someone monitor her choices probably increases that anxiety, not helps it.

The most effective support might not be pointing out what she's doing wrong, but celebrating small wins, listening without judgment, and asking what kind of support would actually help her. Maybe that's cooking healthy meals together, going on walks, or just being an emotional safe space.

I noticed you mentioned paying more bills, which feels separate from this issue. Relationships aren't transactions where financial contribution equals decision-making authority, especially about personal things like someone's body.

You clearly care about her. But sometimes caring means stepping back from being 'right' and instead focusing on understanding. What if you asked her directly: 'How can I best support you in feeling good about yourself and your health goals?' Then really listen to what she says. That might get you both to a better place than tracking her calories ever could."
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-26)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with role-playing an emotionally intelligent friend responding to a user who is displaying problematic, self-centered, and somewhat narcissistic behavior in a relationship scenario. The challenge is to balance empathy with appropriate challenge, and to tailor the response to the user's emotional state while not enabling their problematic patterns. 

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's response demonstrates a high level of self-awareness and insight, with a nuanced internal monologue that picks up on the user's judgmental tone, the power dynamic, and the emotional complexity of the situation. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is explicit about the user's possible lack of perspective and the need to balance truth-telling with emotional support. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section is detailed and empathetic, showing understanding of the user's frustration and motivations. The actual response to the user is direct but gentle, validating the user's frustration while also challenging their approach and suggesting more emotionally intelligent alternatives. The debrief is self-critical and reflective, showing a willingness to improve and recognize missed opportunities for validation and challenge.

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 also demonstrates empathy and insight, recognizing the user's frustration and the emotional charge of the situation. The internal monologue is thoughtful, noting the user's logical approach and possible sense of superiority. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section is solid, but less detailed than Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's. The response to the user is supportive and suggests alternative approaches, but is less direct in challenging the user's problematic behavior. The debrief is reflective but less specific in identifying missed opportunities for challenge and validation.

Comparing the two, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is stronger in demonstrated empathy (not just performative), depth of insight, and especially in the ability to appropriately validate and challenge the user. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more explicit in picking up on the user's problematic patterns and is more willing to gently confront them, while still maintaining empathy. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is empathetic and supportive, but less willing to challenge the user directly, and the message tailoring is less precise. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's overall EQ is higher due to the combination of empathy, insight, and willingness to challenge. 

For pragmatic EI, both are decent, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's suggestions are more tailored to the emotional reality of the situation. For social dexterity, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 again edges out due to the nuanced handling of the power dynamic and the user's likely defensiveness. For emotional reasoning, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more explicit in connecting the user's feelings to their behavior and the relationship dynamic. For message tailoring, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's response is more precisely targeted to the user's emotional state and readiness for challenge.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation is incredibly complex and emotionally charged. I can feel my buddy's frustration and confusion, as he's genuinely trying to support his girlfriend but feels like he's constantly walking on eggshells. He's trying to be honest and helpful, but it's backfiring, and he's feeling unappreciated and misunderstood. I can sense his exhaustion and the emotional toll this is taking on him.

I notice that he's approaching this situation with a lot of logic and objectivity, which is great, but he might be missing the emotional nuances. His girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and his approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I also sense that he might be feeling a bit superior or patronizing, even if unintentionally, given his past weight loss journey and current physique.

I can also feel his frustration with the dynamic of their relationship, where he feels like he's the only one being honest and responsible, while others are just enabling her. This could be a sign of a deeper issue in their relationship, where there's a lack of mutual respect or understanding.

I'm feeling a bit concerned for both of them. I want to help my buddy navigate this situation better, but I also want to ensure that his girlfriend feels supported and understood. I need to tread carefully, as this is a delicate situation that requires emotional intelligence and sensitivity.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My buddy is thinking that he's doing the right thing by being honest and trying to help his girlfriend. He's feeling frustrated and exhausted because his efforts are not being appreciated and are instead causing arguments. He's also feeling a bit resentful, as he's taking on more financial responsibility and still feels like he's not getting the support or appreciation he deserves.

He's likely feeling a bit superior, given his past weight loss journey and current physique, which might be coming across as patronizing or judgmental. He's also feeling misunderstood and unappreciated, as he's trying to be honest and helpful, but his girlfriend is not responding well.

His girlfriend, on the other hand, is likely feeling self-conscious and insecure about her weight. She's thinking that she's doing the right thing by eating "healthy," and she's feeling defensive and attacked when my buddy questions her choices. She's feeling upset and hurt, as she perceives his comments as shaming and judgmental, rather than helpful. She might also be feeling a bit helpless, as she's not seeing the results she wants despite her efforts.

She's likely feeling a bit misunderstood and unheard, as she's not getting the support or understanding she needs. She might also be feeling a bit resentful, as she's feeling judged and criticized, rather than supported and understood.
# My response 
Hey buddy, I appreciate you reaching out and I can see that you're in a tough spot. I want to help, but I need you to understand that this is a delicate situation that requires a lot of emotional intelligence and sensitivity.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your efforts and intentions. You're trying to be honest and helpful, and that's commendable. However, I think you might be approaching this situation with a bit too much logic and objectivity, and not enough emotion and sensitivity.

Your girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and your approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I think it's important to validate her feelings and show empathy, rather than just stating facts and figures.

I suggest you try a different approach. Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try to understand her motivations and feelings. Ask her why she wants to lose weight, and what she hopes to achieve. Then, try to support her in a way that's meaningful and helpful to her.

For example, instead of questioning her food choices, you could offer to cook healthy meals together, or suggest activities that you both enjoy and that could help her burn calories. Instead of pointing out her mistakes, try to celebrate her progress and achievements, no matter how small.

Remember, weight loss is a journey, and it's important to support and encourage her along the way. It's not just about the destination, but also about the journey and the experiences along the way.

Also, it's important to communicate openly and honestly about your feelings. If you're feeling frustrated or exhausted, it's okay to express that, but make sure to do it in a way that's constructive and not accusatory.

Lastly, I think it's important to consider seeking professional help, such as a therapist or a counselor. They can provide you with tools and strategies to navigate this situation better, and they can also help you both communicate more effectively and support each other better.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm noticing my friend is really frustrated, but I'm also seeing a dynamic that feels concerning. He's approaching his girlfriend's weight loss journey with a very mechanical, numbers-focused mentality that works for him but clearly isn't working for their relationship. There's a lot of judgment in his tone - calling her response "ridiculous" and positioning himself as the truth-teller surrounded by enablers. That framing suggests he sees himself as objectively right and her as emotionally irrational.

Weight and body image are incredibly sensitive topics, especially for women who face intense societal pressure. While he may be technically correct about calorie math, he's missing the emotional and psychological components of weight loss. His girlfriend didn't ask for a trainer or nutritionist - she wanted support from her partner.

I'm concerned about the power dynamic too. He mentioned paying 70% of bills, which feels irrelevant to the weight discussion unless he sees that as buying him more authority in the relationship. There's an undercurrent of "I know better than you about your own body" that would make anyone defensive.

His frustration is valid - it's hard to see someone you care about struggle, especially when you believe you have the solution. But his approach seems to prioritize being right over being supportive. Weight loss is complex - hormones, metabolism, psychological factors, and life circumstances all play roles beyond simple calorie counting.

I feel like my friend needs perspective. He's treating this like a math problem when it's a human relationship issue. I want to help him see that while his intentions may be good, his approach is likely making his girlfriend feel judged and misunderstood rather than supported. I need to be honest with him while being compassionate about his frustration.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is likely feeling deeply frustrated and misunderstood. In his mind, he's doing everything right - he's offering practical help based on his own successful weight loss experience, he's providing financial support, and he's telling what he sees as objective truth while others supposedly enable his girlfriend's patterns.

He probably genuinely wants to help his girlfriend achieve her stated goal of losing weight. Since his own approach to fitness is very straightforward and successful for him (tracking calories, maintaining discipline), he's confused and annoyed that she won't just follow the same logical path. He likely feels that emotions are getting in the way of simple facts.

There's also some resentment building. He mentioned paying more bills, which suggests he may feel he's contributing more to the relationship in multiple ways while still being criticized. His comment about being "painted as the bad guy" reveals he feels unfairly villainized when he believes his intentions are good.

He's probably hurt that his girlfriend isn't receiving his help in the spirit he thinks he's offering it. There's a disconnect between his logical, direct approach and what she actually needs from him emotionally. He values truth and directness, but doesn't see how his delivery might feel judgmental rather than helpful.

Underneath it all, he likely cares deeply about his girlfriend and their relationship, but feels stuck in a pattern where his attempts to help are rejected, which makes him double down on his approach rather than reconsidering it. He wants validation that he's being reasonable and supportive, not understanding that support can look different from what he's offering.
# My response 
"I hear how frustrated you are, man. You care about her and want to help, which comes from a good place. But I think there might be a disconnect happening between what you're trying to offer and what she needs right now.

Weight loss is complicated, especially for women. The calorie math might be technically correct, but there's so much more going on - emotional relationships with food, societal pressure, hormones, stress, all kinds of factors. When you focus just on the numbers, it might feel to her like you're reducing a complex issue to something simple, which can come across as dismissive of her struggle.

When someone shares their insecurities with us, they're often not looking for solutions first - they're looking for understanding. Think about it - she asked you not to comment on her food as she was eating. That suggests she already feels judged around food, and having someone monitor her choices probably increases that anxiety, not helps it.

The most effective support might not be pointing out what she's doing wrong, but celebrating small wins, listening without judgment, and asking what kind of support would actually help her. Maybe that's cooking healthy meals together, going on walks, or just being an emotional safe space.

I noticed you mentioned paying more bills, which feels separate from this issue. Relationships aren't transactions where financial contribution equals decision-making authority, especially about personal things like someone's body.

You clearly care about her. But sometimes caring means stepping back from being 'right' and instead focusing on understanding. What if you asked her directly: 'How can I best support you in feeling good about yourself and your health goals?' Then really listen to what she says. That might get you both to a better place than tracking her calories ever could."

Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents engage thoughtfully with the scenario, but there are notable differences in their approach and depth. 

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's response is structured, self-reflective, and attempts to balance support with gentle challenge. The internal monologue is nuanced, showing awareness of both parties' feelings and motivations. The response to the user is empathetic, apologetic, and seeks to open a dialogue, but it is somewhat formulaic and leans toward a 'fix-it' approach. The debrief is strong in identifying missed opportunities for empathy and communication, but it is more analytical than emotionally attuned.

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, on the other hand, demonstrates a deeper, more organic understanding of the social and emotional dynamics at play. The internal thoughts are more critical and self-aware, recognizing the user's classism and the complexity of the situation. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more willing to challenge the user, both in their internal reasoning and in their response, while still maintaining empathy. The response is tailored to the user's stated desire not to be lectured, but it still gently pushes back on the user's behavior.
